Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: NMR, MS, Marfey's, Fractionation techniques
This class was independent research, I learned many lab techniques and assays as well as researching novel biological assays.

The aspect of research for credit that taught me the most was were doing the write-ups and presentation. This was good practice in scientific communication, and although it was a little challenging, it was in that good way where you feel you are learning something. Of course, you do some lab work as well.
I gained lab skills that are very relevant to what I hope to do post-graduation.
Research for credit...basically what you would expect XD
I learned how to think more in-depth about my research project and do research more purposefully.
Lab skills!

I gained a knowledge and and proficiency of common laboratory procedures.  Further, I learned to propose a research project, plan out experiments, gather and analyze scientific data, and write a scientific research report.
I worked on my own research project and practiced presenting as well as writing a research report.
Great opportunity to learn hands-on techniques in chemistry and chemical biology
The class is credit for research and has only strengths. The final paper is a bit stressful and due really early, so that could be better managed.

I think the biggest issue with this course is that very little can be done in the lab with only 10 hours a week, especially if you run into any significant road blocks while working. That being said, I don't know if there is any easy solution to this since raising the bar to anything more than 10 hours a week would be outrageous considering how busy Yale undergrads already are.
Also, I think it would be a good idea for the course to implement a first draft for the final paper that way students are forced to start working on it a little earlier and can also get some feedback before it is due. Not realizing that it was supposed to be a 15-page professional-appearing paper, I started way too late on it.
I worked wayyyyy too many hours beyond the required 10

Strengths: Not a ton of course work, making it possible to focus on your research; flexible assignments
Weakness: Sometimes the requirements (mostly of my PI/mentor) were unclear, so maybe one organizational meeting or some more communication from Dr. Garen would be helpful.

Strengths: You get to work in a real lab for a letter grade credit.
Weaknesses: The 2 short required assignments were tedious but definitely manageable and helpful for summarizing your work.
The level of external work: research proposal and lab report, was just right for me to have a concrete visualization of what I've done in lab while not being too much work.
The greatest strength of this course was my research supervisor and the lab in which I research.

The course is good to pursue personal research with clear expectations. However, improvements could be made through PIs and mentors discussing with students their progress more openly so that they know what is expected of them on the lab-level.
Definitely
I would recommend it to a student that is interested in research. If they have a good PI then it is a good class to do.

Honestly, I would not recommend taking this course unless you have a fair amount of free time and are looking to continue on a project you've already made a head-start on. Giving up 10 hours a week in the Yale schedule can really suck away your life, but putting in 10 hours a week in the lab really doesn't get you very far. Therefore, you're giving up a LOT of time an opportunity for something that just can't be done efficiently during the school year. The course isn't really challenging just time consuming  which worsens that feeling that you're wasting your time. Maybe if you are a senior and more of less done with your course requirements, then taking this class wold be a good idea, but taking this a junior while so much else is going on has not been great.
Yes, but sometimes it feels like when youre going over your hours that youre missing out valuable time towards other courses
Any MB&B major should take advantage of this wonderful opportunity and take it.
Yes! Get credit for your lab hours!
Might as well take this, especially if youre already working in a lab.
I would recommend this course to any student wishing to pursue a career in biology or genetics research as the knowledge gained through this course is invaluable.
If you would like to pursue personal research and get credit, this is good. Be ready to write a rather large report at the end, though.
Yes, you should do research for credit if you are interested in going into biochemistry/biophysics (or medical school).
